Line 26: Line 26:
The application was initially offered under a [[proprietary]] software license. In January 2007, after several years of development, VirtualBox OSE (Open Source Edition) was released under [[GNU General Public License]] (GPL) version 2,<ref>http://www.virtualbox.org/wiki/GPL "The VirtualBox Open Source Edition is licensed under the GPL V2."</ref>. Currently, there is a proprietary version, VirtualBox, which is free only for personal or evaluation use, subject to the VirtualBox Personal Use and Evaluation License (PUEL)<ref>[http://www.virtualbox.org/wiki/VirtualBox_PUEL VirtualBox_PUEL - VirtualBox<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> and an Open Source Edition(OSE), VirtualBox OSE, which is free for commercial and private use, subject to [[Copyleft]] and other requirements of the [[GPL]] license.
The application was initially offered under a [[proprietary]] software license. In January 2007, after several years of development, VirtualBox OSE (Open Source Edition) was released under [[GNU General Public License]] (GPL) version 2,<ref>http://www.virtualbox.org/wiki/GPL "The VirtualBox Open Source Edition is licensed under the GPL V2."</ref>. Currently, there is a proprietary version, VirtualBox, which is free only for personal or evaluation use, subject to the VirtualBox Personal Use and Evaluation License (PUEL)<ref>[http://www.virtualbox.org/wiki/VirtualBox_PUEL VirtualBox_PUEL - VirtualBox<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> and an Open Source Edition(OSE), VirtualBox OSE, which is free for commercial and private use, subject to [[Copyleft]] and other requirements of the [[GPL]] license.

Innotek also contributed to the development of OS/2 support in virtualization products from [[Connectix]] which were later acquired by [[Microsoft]]. Specifically, innotek developed the âadditionsâ code in both [[Virtual PC]] and [[Virtual Server]], which greatly improves host-guest OS interactions. OS/2 has been notoriously difficult to run virtualized in the past due to extensive [[ring (computer security)|ring 2]] execution.
+
Innotek also contributed to the development of OS/2 support in virtualization products from [[Connectix]] which were later acquired by [[Microsoft]]. Specifically, innotek developed the âadditionsâ code in both [[Microsoft Virtual PC]] and [[Microsoft Virtual Server]], which greatly improves host-guest OS interactions. OS/2 has been notoriously difficult to run virtualized in the past due to extensive [[ring (computer security)|ring 2]] execution.
[[Sun Microsystems]] acquired innotek in February 2008.<ref>{{cite press release
